documentType: legal memorandum or expert consultation notes
summary: This document appears to be notes from a November 7, 2021 call with Dr. Rocchio, an AUSA, discussing psychological literature and expert testimony relevant to a case involving sexual assault. It critiques defense expert Dr. Dietz's analysis of PTSD and victim behavior, references literature on grooming and coercive control, and mentions materials filed in a Daubert motion regarding expert testimony.

persons.name: Dr. Rocchio
persons.context: Participant in a call discussing psychological literature and expert testimony related to sexual assault cases, specifically critiquing defense expert analysis.

persons.name: Dietz
persons.context: Defense expert whose analysis of PTSD and victim behavior is being critiqued in the call. The notes challenge his conclusions about victim avoidance behaviors.

persons.name: Dr. Jennifer Freyd
persons.context: Cited for her work on betrayal trauma literature, which examines how people can maintain relationships with perpetrators.

persons.name: Loftus
persons.context: Mentioned in the defense expert notice, likely another expert for the defense.

connections.description: Dr. Rocchio, representing the government, is critiquing the analysis and conclusions of defense expert Dietz in the context of a legal proceeding.

events.title: Expert Consultation Call
events.description: A call between Dr. Rocchio (AUSA) and an unspecified participant(s) to discuss psychological literature, PTSD, victim behavior, and critique defense expert testimony for a case.

keyFacts: The document critiques defense expert Dr. Dietz's conclusion that sexual assault survivors would avoid reminders of the assault, arguing it ignores literature on ongoing abusive relationships and coercive control.
It references betrayal trauma literature (Dr. Jennifer Freyd) explaining how victims can maintain relationships with perpetrators as an adaptive mechanism.
The notes discuss the 'Bennett article' on grooming, noting it lacks an error rate but provides a good conceptual review, though its Daubert opinion was a 'side comment'.
Legal materials referenced include a defense motion to exclude Rocchio's testimony, government opposition, and defense expert notices for Dietz and Loftus, indicating active Daubert challenges.
The document challenges the idea that PTSD-related avoidance precludes victims from having ongoing contact with perpetrators, citing reasons like minimization, denial, and coercive control.
